resources.string: The project is to design a smart phone app analyzing the indoor air concentration of formaldehyde: the users will expose the chemical sensor indoor, then take a picture through SmART-Form app. The app will recognize the color identity of chemical sensor and return the result of air concentration of formaldehyde. \n\n Shane
Enter a title for the test.

Instructions:

1.You should have an electronic or paper copy of images of badges “before” and “after” exposures. These are just images and there will be no color change during this beta test. These images are provided so that you can give us feedback on use of the app. 
2.Open the app and select “New test” 
3.Name your test and take a picture of the test location 
4.Select the “Before” button and take a picture of the “Before” image 
5.Pretend to wait 72 hours (you can move forward right away) 
6.Select the “After” button and take a picture of the “After” image 
7.Select “Upload my data to database” 
8.Complete the sampling survey as much as you would like (this data will not be used for research purposes, but this section is available so you can give us feedback on the survey) 
9.Complete the follow-up beta testing survey
There are currently no tests to display.
%1$s: The test was created on %2$s. %3$s, and the result is %4$s.

COPYRIGHTS:

Copyright 2017 SMARTFORM.

All Rights Reserved.


SmartPhone App for Residential Testing of Formaldehyde (SmART-Form)

This is a consent form for your participation in this research study.


The purpose of this research project is to develop a low-cost and highly accurate technique for assessing domestic formaldehyde concentrations and is being conducted by Ohio State University in conjunction with the Public Laboratory for Open Technology and Science (Public Lab). Insights from citizen scientists and other relevant members of the public is key to developing the most robust and useable technology possible.


You are invited to participate in this research project because you are: A member of an environmental or citizen science organization (Public Lab, Global Community Monitor, or the Sierra Club’s formaldehyde campaign) A resident of Waycross, GA where the technology developed by this project will be first deployed.


Your participation in this research study is voluntary. You may choose not to participate. If you decide to participate in this research survey, you may withdraw at any time. If you decide not to participate in this study or if you withdraw from participating at any time, there will be no penalty or loss of benefits that the participant is entitled to. You may skip any questions you do not wish to answer. If you want do not wish to complete this survey just close your browser.


The procedure involves filling an online survey that will take approximately 20 minutes. Your responses will be confidential and we do not collect identifying information such as your name, email address or IP address. The survey questions will be about your interest in testing for airborne formaldehyde, how we should build the software and hardware for this technology to best suit your needs, and reflections on past community science studies (if applicable).


We will work to make sure that no one sees your survey responses without approval. But, because we are using the Internet, there is a chance that someone could access your online responses without permission. In some cases, this information could be used to identify you. Your data will be protected with a code to reduce the risk that other people can view the responses. We will do our best to keep your information confidential. All data is stored in a password protected electronic format. To help protect your confidentiality, the surveys will not contain information that will personally identify you. The results of this study will be used for scholarly, technical development, public education purposes only and may be shared with Ohio State University representatives.


For questions, concerns, or complaints about the study, or you feel you have been harmed as a result of study participation, you may contact Karen Dannemiller at 614-292-4031.


For questions about your rights as a participant in this study or to discuss other study-related concerns or complaints with someone who is not part of the research team, you may contact Ms. Sandra Meadows in the Office of Responsible Research Practices at 1-800-678-6251.This research has been reviewed according to Ohio State University IRB procedures for research involving human subjects.


Please print a copy of this consent form for your records, if you so desire.


ELECTRONIC CONSENT: Please select your choice below.


Clicking on the "agree" button below indicates that:

*You have ready the above information

*You voluntarily agree to participate

*You are at least 18 years of age


If you do not wish to participate in the research study, please decline participation by clicking on the "disagree" button.
